citeinfo.title: Design and analysis protocols for survey and manage species under the Pacific Northwest Forest Plan

pubinfo.publish: USGS Forest and Rangeland Ecosystem Science Center

descript.abstract: A basic goal of the Pacific Northwest Forest Management Plan is to implement management activities that maintain biodiversity. The Record of Decision leading to the Plan highlights >400 species of concern in the area the Plan covers, extending roughly from California north of Mt. Shasta to the Canadian border, and west of the Cascades. The species of concern include fungi, lichens, bryophytes, mollusks, and several vascular plants, arthropods and vertebrates. Collectively, these species and species groups are referred to as survey and manage species. This designation reflects, in part, recognition that limited information is currently available for these species and species groups, and that appropriate survey methods must be developed to ascertain impacts of management decisions. Most of the species are known from relatively few sample sites, and the extent of their spatial distributions is unclear. Even less information is known about basic life history attributes. In one sense, the survey and manage species represent rare events in time and space. Many exhibit irruptive population behavior, appearing only for brief time periods or only once or twice over extended time periods. They can also be rare in space, with large distances between populations. These characteristics provide unique statistical challenges to surveys designed to provide quantifiable estimates about the species.
